emergency.name: Hospital General de Agudos José María Ramos Mejía

tips: Use 'Radio Taxi' or apps for cabs; street taxis can pose a risk. Be aware of pickpockets, especially on crowded subways/buses (Subtes/Colectivos).
Carry a copy of your passport and leave the original in a safe place.
Explore the city's historic universities and student life.
Enjoy the local *alfajores* (sweet biscuits) and regional *empanadas*.
Rent a bicycle to tour the Maipú wine region independently.
Dress in layers for the 'High Mountain Tour' as temperatures change rapidly near the Andes.

attractions.name: National Flag Memorial (Monumento a la Bandera)

tips: Rosario is famous for being the birthplace of Lionel Messi and Che Guevara.
Enjoy a stroll along the Paraná River promenade.

attractions.name: Playa Grande
attractions.address: Mar del Plata, Buenos Aires Province

tips: The city is a major summer beach destination, extremely crowded from December to February.
Seafood is the local specialty here.

attractions.name: Museo de Arqueología de Alta Montaña (MAAM)

tips: Explore the Quebrada de Humahuaca day trip for stunning colored mountains.
Salta is known for its folklore music (Peñas) and crisp white Torrontés wine.

attractions.name: Museo del Fin del Mundo (End of the World Museum)

tips: This is the world's southernmost city; prepare for cold, unpredictable weather, even in summer.
Ushuaia is the departure point for cruises to Antarctica.
The best way to see the Perito Moreno Glacier is a boat tour or a 'minitrekking' ice walk.
Strong winds are common; layers are essential.

restaurants.name: Mercado de Comida Callejera (Street Food Market)

tips: Hydrate constantly and take it slow to adjust to the high altitude (approx. 3,640m).
Do not photograph police or military buildings.
Sucre is Bolivia's constitutional capital and known for its colonial white architecture.
Try the local *salteñas* (baked savory pastry) for breakfast.
The climate is tropical, contrasting with the high altitude of La Paz.
Santa Cruz is Bolivia's economic hub; it has a more modern, commercial feel.

emergency.address: Av. Afranio de Melo Franco, Leblon

tips: Avoid carrying valuables on Copacabana and Ipanema beaches.
Taxis/apps are recommended at night; public transport is extensive but requires caution.

attractions.name: MASP (Museum of Art of São Paulo)

tips: São Paulo is vast; plan transport carefully, as traffic is notorious. The metro is very efficient.
It is the country’s gastronomic capital; try a *rodízio* pizza.
Salvador is the heart of Afro-Brazilian culture. Try *Acarajé* and local Baiana cuisine.
Be highly aware of your surroundings, especially in the Lower City (*Cidade Baixa*).
The city is divided into numbered sectors (quadras); addresses can be confusing.
Brasília is spread out; taxis or rideshares are necessary to see the major sites.
Manaus is the gateway to the Amazon. Book jungle tours with reputable operators.
Be mindful of pickpockets in busy areas like the port and market.
Recife is nicknamed the 'Venice of Brazil' for its waterways and bridges.
Be cautious of shark warnings and adhere to local beach safety rules.
Fortaleza is known for its vibrant nightlife and *forró* music.
Book a buggy tour to explore the sand dunes outside the city.
BH is the capital of Minas Gerais state, known for its unique *mineira* food.
The city has an excellent 'boteco' (bar) culture; it is famous for its beer.
Curitiba is known for its high quality of life and innovative public transport (Bus Rapid Transit).
Take the scenic Serra Verde Express train ride to Morretes.
Porto Alegre is the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, known for its Gaucho culture and traditions.
Enjoy the sunset over the Guaíba River.
Known as 'Ilha da Magia' (Magic Island), it's a paradise for surfers and beach lovers.
You will need a car or ride-share to explore the various beaches on the island.

attractions.name: Forte dos Reis Magos (Three Wise Men Fort)

tips: Natal is near the world's largest cashew tree.
The city's biggest beach is Ponta Negra, which has great dining options.

restaurants.name: Boragó (Fine Dining)
restaurants.address: Av. San Josemaría Escrivá de Balaguer 5970

tips: The city has excellent metro system; buy a Bip! card.
Chilean wine is world-renowned; take a day trip to the Casablanca Valley or Maipo Valley.
Ride the historic *ascensores* (funiculars) for scenic views.
Try *Chorrillana*, a local dish of fries, meat, and eggs.
Viña is the more affluent, beach-oriented neighbor of Valparaíso.
Enjoy the beaches like Reñaca, but swimming can be restricted due to cold water/currents.

attractions.name: Pérez Rosales National Park (Vicente Pérez Rosales)

tips: This is the starting point for exploring Chile's Lake District and Patagonia.
The local specialty is *curanto*, a traditional seafood and meat stew cooked in a pit.

emergency.name: Posta de San Pedro de Atacama

tips: Altitude sickness is a risk; acclimatize slowly and stay hydrated.
It is one of the best stargazing spots on earth; book an astronomical tour.

restaurants.name: Andrés Carne de Res (Chia location is famous)

tips: Try the local specialty *Ajiaco* (potato and chicken soup).
Security varies by neighborhood; be cautious in crowded areas and use taxis/apps at night.
Known as the 'City of Eternal Spring' for its pleasant climate.
Take the MetroCable for stunning views and to understand the city's transformation and urban planning.
The Walled City is best explored in the early morning or evening to avoid the intense heat.
Street vendors can be persistent; a polite 'No, gracias' is usually sufficient.
Cali is the world capital of Salsa; take a dance lesson or visit a *salsateca*.
Try the local drink *cholado* (fruit, syrup, and crushed ice).
Visit during Carnival (February/March) for the largest street party in Colombia.
The city is hot and humid; dress in light clothing.
This is the oldest surviving city in Colombia, located on the Caribbean coast.
Use local buses (*colectivos*) to reach nearby beaches and Tayrona Park.
The city is at high altitude (2,850m); take time to acclimatize and avoid strenuous activity immediately.
The Historic Center is very safe during the day, but use taxis at night.
Guayaquil is hotter and more tropical than Quito. It's the economic hub.
Be mindful of petty crime, especially on public buses and in crowded markets.
The city is known for its beautiful colonial architecture and large expatriate community.
Cuenca is a great base for day trips to Cajas National Park.
Montañita is a laid-back, bohemian surf town known for its relaxed atmosphere and parties.
Be highly vigilant about personal belongings due to opportunistic theft.
Guyana is the only English-speaking country in South America.
Avoid walking alone at night, especially in the downtown area. Use reputable taxi services.
The Guaraní language is widely spoken alongside Spanish.
The historic center is safe during the day, but quiet at night. Enjoy the traditional *chipá* bread.

attractions.name: Plaza Mayor de Lima (Plaza de Armas)

tips: Lima is the gastronomic capital of South America; book top restaurants far in advance.
Miraflores, Barranco, and San Isidro are the safest neighborhoods for tourists.
Cusco is the base for Machu Picchu. Use the tourist ticket (Boleto Turístico) for multiple sites.
Be mindful of high altitude (3,400m); consider a day or two of rest upon arrival.
The city is nicknamed the 'White City' for its architecture made of *sillar* (volcanic white stone).
Try *Rocoto Relleno* (stuffed spicy pepper), the local dish.

attractions.name: Huaca del Sol y de la Luna (Moche Pyramids)

tips: Trujillo is the capital of the 'Marinera' dance and known for its vibrant celebrations.
The nearby beach town of Huanchaco is famous for its *caballitos de totora* (reed boats).

restaurants.name: Al Frío y Al Fuego (Floating Restaurant)

tips: Iquitos is the largest city in the world inaccessible by road (only by air or river).
Beware of unauthorized guides offering jungle tours; use licensed operators.
Suriname is a former Dutch colony; Dutch, Sranan Tongo, and English are spoken.
Try the unique Javanese-Surinamese and Hindustani-Surinamese food.
Uruguay is generally considered the safest country in South America.
Try *chivito* (a large steak sandwich) and *medio y medio* (wine spritzer).
A luxury resort town, it is extremely busy and expensive during the high summer season (Jan/Feb).
There are two main beaches: Mansa (calm) and Brava (rough).
This city is a popular and easy day trip via ferry from Buenos Aires, Argentina.
Rent a golf cart or bicycle to explore the small, quaint city center.
Due to political and economic instability, visitors must exercise extreme caution. Travel only in daylight and use trusted, pre-arranged transport.
Local dishes include *arepas* and *hallacas* (seasonal).
